paper_abstract: The (maximal) exponent of a non-empty finite word is the ratio of its length to its period. Dejean (1972) conjectured that for any n >= 5 there exists an infinite word over n letters with no factor of its exponent larger than n/(n - 1). We prove that this conjecture is true for n >= 33. (c) 2007 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: On Dejean's conjecture over large alphabets
